abstracts.cdata!:
The National AIDS Control Program
            Assistance Project for Zaire achieved an unsatisfactory
            overall outcome. Its institutional development impact is
            negligible and its sustainability is unlikely. The project
            had little impact on the evolution of the AIDS epidemic in
            Zaire and made slight contribution to the development of the
            country's capacity to combat AIDS. Despite a strong
            technical design, the project suffered from weak project
            management and low government commitment. Rapid
            deterioration of Zaire's socio-political, physical, and
            financial environment, including looting of project premises
            in 1991 and 1993, created increasingly difficult conditions
            for the project. IDA's decision to extend the project
            implementation period for two and a half years in 1992
            reflected the expectation that positive political changes at
            the time would turn Zaire's chaotic conditions around,
            but the situation soon resumed its downward spiral.
            Disbursements were suspended in July 1993 and non-accrual
            status was declared in November 1993. The project was closed
            in January 1994 with only 41 percent of the IDA credit
            disbursed. The Bank's leadership in developing a
            standalone AIDS project helped to raise the perceived
            priority of AIDS in Zaire and in the Bank, and the technical
            content of the project was basically sound. However, the
            project at times suffered from the inadequacy and
            irregularity of Bank supervision. The Borrower's
            performance exhibited weak leadership and management and
            ultimately was responsible for the disappointing outcome of
            the project. Lessons learned revolve around dealing with
            hostile implementation environments, the quality and
            training of staffing, and Bank supervision and policies.
